title: stacey dooley arms dealing
story: Instead, the Arkansas mum became a gun dealer – negotiating international arms and weapons deals worth up to £. billion a time.In BBC’s Stacey Dooley: Face to Face with Arms Dealers, which airs today, the Strictly star investigates whether the weapons they sell are protecting or killing us.It takes her to the southern state where more than half the population own a gun.But its not just the local market who are interested in what Gretchens business, Thor Global Defence Group, can offer.America is the worlds biggest exporter of arms and the industry is worth £billion a year to the US economy, employing , workers and Gretchens company sells to more than  countries - over half in the world.If someone wanted a -feet shipping container of AKs, Gretchen is who you go to for it.At her workplace, which looks like a gun shop with a shooting range, she reveals she has grenade launchers stored downstairs.most read in world news" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-comp-mcbrawl.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" SENT FRY-ING Woman tosses bloke around ‘like a rag doll’ in viral McDonald’s fight video " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   KH-COMPOSITE-BIVENS-.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" BLOODBATH Baseball stars we, son  mum-in-law killed by teen relative on naked rampage " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   SM-COMP-BIRTH.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" ‘NOBODY WAS HELPING ME’ Distressing video shows woman giving birth alone in jail cell " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-comp-guy.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" WarningSTAB ATTACK Moment knewoman randomly stabs boy as he walks down the street with parents " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-comp-capone.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" ExclusiveMOBSTER’S MILLIONS Al Capones niece says she knows the house his m fortunes hidden in " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   AD-COMPOSITE-Epstein-Trump.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" PRINCE  THE PAEDO Prince Andrew pictured partying with paedo pal Epstein and Donald Trump Gretchen says using guns is justied because it’s “sheer defence”.“As an American we are born and grow up being taught about guns,” she tells Stacey.“I can’t imagine living in a place that I didn’t have the right to strap a gun on and not be a victim.”I wont go to London - its too dangerous. You guys have a real problem with terrorist attacks, rapes are very high, stabbings.Gretchen has no military background but reveals she decided to swap domesticity for le in the male-dominated and secretive arms industry after her brother, Alan, narrowly avoided death in the   terror attacks in .They were watching the attacks on the news when they realised that Alan could have been one of the planes that crashed into the Twin Towers, killing everyone on board.I didnt know where he was, and that was the worst thing, thats when it kicks in, says Gretchen. We didnt know how many were taken. We didnt know anything.“I’m frightened I can’t defend the people I love. I pray for the best and prepare for the worst.But it is absolute sheer defence. I want military to have quality weapons, and defend people like you.”Although she admits she is “frightened of guns”, Stacey is given a lesson in shooting a rle and Thor’s most prestigious gun, nicknamed Pandora.She says: “I feel really uneasy and awkward around guns” but Gretchen reassures her, saying: “You’re getting the same training sessions our kids go through. We are going to teach you right along with our children, with my daughter, she is .If the time comes you have to drop the camera and pick up a weapon you’ll know what to do with it.”Despite her initial reluctance, Stacey surprised herself with her “delighted” reaction when she hit the targets. She also concedes that she does feel safer when in dangerous places with people who carry guns.Stacey sees eight-year-old Richie, the son of the companys CEO fire a gun. He tells her it feels awesomeand that he wants to be a sniper when he grows up.Stacey also visits the manufacturers where she meets factory owner, Wade, who takes her through the process of producing weapons to meet Thor’s specic requirements.Wade explains the serial number of the gun means it can always be traced. If the gun is used for criminal activity, Thor will stop selling to that client.The company takes two weeks to produce  rles, which cost around £, each.To test them, each gun is fired  times as part of the companys “internal policy”, before it is wiped to remove fingerprints, packaged and sent to the client.Only three components are needed to make a bullet: the case, powder and projectile.Although making weapons is a vital part of their work the most important part is the paperwork, whichnot completed correctly could see Gretchen face serious consequences.She said: “We follow the rules. We can lose our licence or go to jail. It’s a federal offence. It could be  years per weaponpaperwork isn’t right.”During filming for the documentary, the terrorist attacks at mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, which killed  people take place.Thor were in the midst of organising an order to a gun shop in New Zealand where the terrorists bought their firearms.Before the attacks, New Zealand gun laws meant anyone over  could own a gun. In the wake of the atrocities, Thor’s order was put on hold.Askedthe attack proves selling arms has dangerous repercussions, Payton says: “I don’t blame all car drivers for one drunk driver. You will find one [bad] person in every business, only we sell things that could cause massacres.”BBC Three’s Stacey Dooley: Face to Face with Arms Dealers is available online on BBC. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Remoaners The Seven is one of  programmes on the new channel that at certain points between February  and June  had zero viewers, according to the British Audience Research Board.That’s quite an achievement, given that Scotland has a population of five-and-a-half million and the average viewer north of the border spends three hours and  minutes a day watching television.Then, in June, the BBC announced it would be breaking its promise to provide free TV licences to the over-s.The Director-General, Tony Hall, agreed to take on that responsibility from the Government as a condition of the BBC’s Royal Charter being renewed in .According to the terms of the deal, the Corporation would be able to put up the licence fee each year and, in , it would fund free TV licences for pensioners from June , .The Beeb’s Royal Charter was duly renewed and the licence fee went up in , in  and again in .Yet apparently it can no longer afford to keep its pledge. From next June, only those over-s on pension credit will be eligible for free TV licences — just one in five people.That means .million pensioners, including more than , service veterans, will have to find £. a yearthey want to continue watching television.To add insult to injury, the BBC then disclosed how much money it is paying its stars.Anti-Brexit activist and Match Of The Day presenter Gary Lineker is on £,,, Graham Norton is on £, and Claudia Winkleman is on £,.Lineker’s salary alone would pay for more than , TV licences.Asthat wasn’t bad enough, earlier this month the Beeb said it intends to spend £million on an advertising campaign to attract young viewers and listeners.That’s more than the annual budget of Radio .It’s particularly high, given that the BBC can advertise on its own TV channels and radio stations for free. Apparently, the money is going to be spent on targeting young people on social media.Are we really supposed to believe that the BBC cannot afford to pay for pensioners’ TV licences, but can fritter away £million on Facebook adverts There’s almost nothing Auntie won’t stoop to in its desperate pursuit of the “yoof” audience.It has earmarked £million to promote its new Sounds app — including spending £, to transform the London Eye into the “London Ear” — and poured money into a series of increasingly tawdry podcasts, such as Gemma Collins talking about her le, a reality-show round-up called Reality Tea, and Unexpected Fluids, in which teenagers tell embarrassing ­stories about when sex goes wrong.It’s all a far cry from Lord Reith’s mission to explain.No doubt the BBC is concerned about how few young people it manages to attract — and this manests itself in other ways, too, such as its massive investment in apps and podcasts and its extensive online coverage of ITV’s Love Island.Last year, Ofcom revealed that  to -year-olds are spending an average of an hour and  minutes per day consuming BBC content, which is about half the amount for all age groups.Even more worrying for the Corporation, one in eight young Brits consumes no BBC content at all. Why should they fork out £. for the licence fee, particularly as many of them will already be paying for subscription TV services The fundamental problem the Beeb faces is that consumers are becomingly increasingly accustomed to paying for the TV content they want to watch and resent having to pay a mandatory flat tax to a single provider.The equivalent would beeveryone who owns a phone, tablet or laptop had to pay £. for an “internet licence” to fund Apple’s iTunes, regardless of whether or not they use the service.It’s time to do away with the licence fee — for everyone, not just the over-s.That would mean stripping down the state-funded parts of the BBC to its core news and current affairs output and funding that out of general taxation.It should sell off its profitable private isions — such as BBC Studios, which has annual revenues of more than £billion — and plough the money into creating its own subscription service.With its global brand recognition and unrivalled back catalogue, not to mention its reputation for high-quality drama, the BBC could easily compete with commercial providers such as Netflix and Amazon Prime.Promising to scrap the licence fee would surely be a vote-winner for Boris Johnson.What other election pledge would save nearly every British household £. a year No s, no buts. When it comes to renewing the BBC’s Royal Charter, it’s time to say: “No deal.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew jeffery epstein reputation
story: Nobody is accusing him of any wrongdoing. But his statement over the weekend still left plenty of questions to answer, not least why he continued to pal up with Epstein even after the tycoon was locked up for a year for soliciting an underage prostitute.The Royal Family has been a rock of stability in British le for centuries, and while its members are — obviously — unelected, they are held to a higher standard. Prince Andrew’s explanation, such as it was, didn’t meet that bar.And in it, he also blamed the media an increasingly easy way for public ­figures to attempt to dodge legitimate questions.The truth isit wasn’t for the media, we wouldn’t know anything at all about the Prince’s relationship with Epstein a matter of profound public interest.If reports are correct that the Duke of York will help police with their inquiries, then good on him. The public deserve to hear from him, too. A sit-down interview wouldn’t be the worst idea.The only way to put this sorry saga to bed, for the Royal Family as a whole, is for Prince Andrew to accept that he does have questions to answer. Sunlight is still the best disinfectant.WE wouldn’t trust our no-to-no-deal politicians to organise a booze-up in a brewery. Corbyn wants to be Prime Minister, but the Lib Dems don’t agree.The unbearable Tory rebels are  per cent committed to stopping a clean break as long as they don’t lose their seat. And Change UK  Answers on a postcard, please.There are bulls running around china shops with more sense of order.The contrast between the hapless democracy-deniers on one side and the Government couldn’t be more obvious.Boris, until October , has one job. Deliver on the result of the  Referendum, and get us out of the EU. His G remarks suggest he knows it.THE Sun couldn’t back the call for Ben Stokes to be knighted any more enthusiastically.Nobody is perfect. Stokes certainly hasn’t been — but then, who is His grace in ­victory is a lesson for all of us. Make no mistake, this is cricket’s summer. From the World Cup to Headingley, it’s been remarkable drama.Now there are two tests to go to bring the urn home. Come on England — and Sir Ben.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: boris has been a revelation since he took over brexit but signing away powers to get it over the line could cost him his job
story: Delivering on the referendum ought to make Nigel Farage’s Brexit Party redundant and ensure a Tory election win. But binning the toxic Irish backstop might not be enough eventhe EU agrees.There is plenty in Theresa May’s deal to bind our hands even after we have left.The Sun would still prefer a deal. But Farage will capitalise, understandably so,Boris signs away any sovereign powers in haste to get Brexit over the line. That could yet cost him power.This may all be moot. We do not see Brussels nor the Irish PM scrapping the backstop they have treated as holy writ.But when his own allies like Iain Duncan Smith warn him not to be satisfied solely with that, Boris must listen.WHO’S up for more years of bitter Brexit ision and political paralysis Not Leavers, who were sick of it long ago and are furious their vote hasn’t been fulfilled. Not the EU, either. Its leaders, Boris says, just want it done now too.But others ARE bent on prolonging the agony indefinitely. What are Labour, the Lib-Dems, the SNP, the Greens and the Exact Change brigade all smoking After all that’s happened, how can they still believe our best bet is to nully the referendum and hold a second, skewed to ensure a Remain verdict  Nothing is more certain to wreck Britain.Yet befuddled Corbyn, led by his scheming sidekick Keir Starmer, has signed Labour up to this lunacy and abandoned his Leave voters entirely.Riding high two years ago, Corbyn is now reduced to feebly branding No Deal a “bankers’ Brexit” or a “Trump-deal Brexit”, apparently unaware bankers funded Remain and that no Trump deal would ever involve the NHS.It is dog-whistle drivel for deranged anti-American Trots and the #FBPE losers whining about Brexit on Twitter.These diehard Remainers, trapped in their bubble, are a truly pitul bunch.THE shake-up of shared ownership rules for hard-up home buyers is a smart idea as far as it goes.But they still have to find or borrow  per cent upfront. Why not slash that to ten, or even one  And it still smacks of tinkering when the solution to turning millennials into home owners is both more obvious and far more radical:A bonfire of archaic planning rules and a massive increase in the total of affordable homes built each year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: remainers porkie pies trade deals
story: By drawing his excited opponents into making accusations about yet more of Boris’s “porky pies”, he has skilfully drawn attention to the point he really wanted to make — that there are huge global opportunities for British food exportersonly we are prepared to make concessions in opening up our own food markets to the world.In fact,we start exporting pork pies to the Far East we will only be ing to what we were doing more than  years ago.In , Melton Mowbray bakers Evans  Hill reported they had received a large order of pork pies from Borneo — which is even further from Britain than Thailand.If we could do it then, without modern refrigeration, we can surely do it now. As Boris was arguing, the real barriers to trade are not practical ones — they are taxes and regulations.Remainers continually lecture us on the benefits of free trade with the EU — and they are right to do so. Hardly anyone really wants to leave without a deal. If we do have to take that route it will surely not be long before discussions on a free trade deal recommence.Yet those same Remainers bizarrely retreat in horror when anyone suggests we do a free trade deal with the US. “But we’ll have to eat chlorinated chicken,” they complain, as well as GM “Frankenstein” food.As shown by their failure yesterday to agree on a common course of action to thwart Brexit, Remainers are bumbling along in a state of confusion.MOST READ IN OPINION" data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   tp-composite-quentin-letts-.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentQUENTIN LETTS Remainers think BoJo hasnt got a Clouseau - but hes got purpose  pazazz " data-srcset"https:i.wp www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg croppx%Cpx%Cpx%Cpxresize%Cssl" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Tory rebels must back Boris or risk unleashing Marxist chaos on the economy " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Remainers have no right to complain now that the tables have turned " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   JBM_COMP-rod-liddle.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentROD LIDDLE Parliament works AGAINST the people so BoJo is right to threaten to suspend it " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   SM-COMP-GIVEITBACK.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentBARONESS GABBY BERTIN Cutting disabled kids care costs the country MORE in the long term " data-srcset"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   NINTCHDBPICT.jpg stripallwhcrop" srcSet"" sizes" px, px"  px, px" CommentTHE SUN SAYS Boris Johnson is not a dictator, he is defending democracy from Remoaners But nothing demonstrates this better than their contradictory approach to free trade. They seem to think it a great benefit to the country when conducted with the EU, but a route to national disastercarried out with any other country.The charge that anyone will be forced to eat chlorinated chicken or GM foods is, needless to say, a far bigger porky pie than anything Boris has said on the subject.It is far from certain that a Johnson Government, when engaged in trade talks with the US, will make the concessions allowing these products into UK markets, butit does, then UK shoppers will continue to have a choice.They will still be able to buy chicken produced in Britain or the EU, or they will be able to choose to eat American chicken.I certainly have no fear of eating chicken which has been washed in chlorine. The idea that it is “dangerous” has been thoroughly debunked. Each of us ingests far more chlorine through drinking water than we ever would do through eating US-produced chicken.As for GM foods, we already eat them, vegans especially. The EU allows imports of GM soyafor simple practical reasons. Most of it is grown in the Americas and too many growers there use GM seed for non-GM soya to be sold as a separate product.If we want free trade we are not going to achieve it just by persuading other countries to open their markets to us. No, we will have to make the concession of opening our markets to them too. But there is no reason to be frightened.True, there are some products which need to be banned from sale for genuine health and safety reasons. But most of the EU’s food product standards are really just a form of protectionism in disguise, dreamed up to block competition for European farmers.If we do post-Brexit trade deals with the US and other countries — and in the process do away with the EU’s protectionist tarfs and product standards — some UK producers would suffer.But others would prosper as they enjoyed access to new export markets. Overall, as is almost always the case when trade barriers are taken down, we would benefit. Strong industries would grow and consumers would enjoy greater choice and lower prices.Boris’s vision of a global British pork pie industry shows the dference between him and the political opponents who spent much of yesterday scheming over how to stop him taking Britain out of the EU.While his glass is half full, theirs is half empty.They are driven by a pathological fear of le outside the EU.It is not that they have any great enthusiasm for the EU. After all, I haven’t heard one of them make a convincing case why the EU is an institution to be admired. It is just that they have a lack of ambition for Britain and so cling to EU membership.After meeting for several hours yesterday, what did the likes of Jeremy Corbyn, Keir Starmer and Jo Swinson come up with That they want to extend Article  yet further, to prolong yet again the endless drt which unsettled markets and put off investment.Fortunately, the public seems to have come to a very dferent conclusion. It just wants Brexit to be over and done with.Thanks to the Remain lobby’s endless infighting and self-indulgent argument over who it would like as a caretaker Prime Minister, that is exactly what is overwhelmingly likely to happen on October . Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: who is lord young resigned brexit
story: Heres everything we know about the Conservative politician...George Samuel Knatchbull Young, Baron Young of Cookham was a Conservative MP representing North West Hampshire from , and before that Ealing Acton.He is a former Etonian and graduated from the University of Oxford with a degree in Philosophy, Politics and Economics.He was active in student politics while at Oxford, holding ious offices in the Oxford University Conservative Association and being elected to the Standing Committee of the Oxford Union.Young has served in Cabinet three times, as Secretary of State for Transport from  to , as the Leader of the House of Commons and Lord Privy Seal from  to  and as Chief Whip of the House of Commons from  to .As a Conservative Party minister, Lord Young had served under Margaret Thatcher, John Major and David Cameron.Young quit the Commons during the  election and was created a le peer - a title which guarantees Young a seat in the House of Lords.On August  Young resigned as a whip in the House of Lords over Boris Johnsons decision to prorogue parliament.In his resignation letter, Young writes: Following the announcement that parliament is to be prorogued in the week beginning September th, and not due to reconvene until October th, I am afraid I cannot continue to serve in your team in the Lords.Young goes on to claim that his resignation is not primarily about Brexit, although he does think that Boris Johnsons do or die approach to leaving on October  is rash, and that more time could be procured should need be.More time may be needed to get the Withdrawal Agreement through both Houses with the scrutiny it deserves, he writes.Young says he is very unhappy with the timing andof the prorogation of Parliament, as well as the motivation behind the move.He says he is unpersuaded by the reasons given for that decision [to prorogue Parliament] which I believe risks undermining the fundamental role of parliament at a critical time in our history, and reinforces the view that the government may not have the confidence of the House for its Brexit policy.In his letter of resignation, Young insists that he is not part of any remainer plot.

title: coloured tattoos leak toxic metals lymph nodes
story: Researchers have discovered that nickel and chromium, which are allergens, are shed from a tattoo needle when a white pigment is used.The pigment - called titanium dioxide - is often mixed into brighter colours such as blue, green and red.But the new study, from the European Synchrotron Radiation Facilityin Grenoble, France, found that it can cause the needle to erode and so tiny metal particles can enter the skin.Those particles then travel to the lymph nodes, which are small glands that store white blood cells - responsible for killing invading organisms.The researchers claim that the identication of these metals inside the pigment could explain why some people suffer bad reactions to tattoos.In , a study by New York University found that  per cent of people had reported suffering an adverse reaction to a tattoo.But until quite recently, experts had thought it was to do with the inks.Previous research had shown that there were metal nanoparticles in the lymph nodes of tattooed people.They ranged from  nanometres long, or as small as DNA molecule, to two micrometres long, which is about the size of a bacterium cell.Nanoparticles are considered more hazardous than larger particles because they have surface area per volume, which can cause a higher release of toxic chemicals.The European Chemicals Agencywarned back in  that some tattoo inks could be toxic, and has called for the banning of the potentially-deadly substances.The organisations report claims that the toxic ink could cause long-lasting skin problems, as well as increasing the risk of cancer.Other side effects include serious allergic reactions to the suspect ink and painful itching which can last for years.Red inks were described as the most dangerous, but blue, green and black inks also came under fire.The agency said: “Many reports show concerns for public health stemming from the composition of inks used for tattooing.“The most severe concerns are allergies caused by the substances in the inks and possible carcinogenic, mutagenic or reproductive toxic effects.”The team at the ESRF wanted to establish whether there was a link between the metal nanoparticles found in the lymph nodes of tattooed people.ESRF scientist Ines Schreiver, who co-authored the research, said: We were following up on our previous study, by trying to find the link between iron, chromium and nickel and the colouring of the inks.After studying several human tissue samples and finding metallic components, we realised that there must be something .Then we thought of testing the needle and that was our eureka moment.They began studying ink sample under an intense X-ray and found that when tattoo ink contains titanium dioxide, the needle can erode.The research, published in the journal Particle and Fibre Toxicology, found that it doesnt happen with carbon black ink, which is softer.Co-author Hiram Castillo added: There is more to tattoos than meet the eye.It is not only about the cleanliness of the parlour, the sterilisation of the equipment or even about the pigments.Now we find that the needle wear also has an impact in your body.These are long-term effects which can only be assessed in long-term epidemiological studies that monitor the health of thousands of people over decades.

title: portsmouth university student bar shuts
story: Undergraduates used to have a reputation for heavy drinking at the union bar.But The Waterhole Bar at the University of Portsmouth has seen a massive drop in alcohol sales and is to be turned into a “social space” with a coffee shop and microwaves.Alcohol sales are down  per cent year on year for the past four years and it has lost more than half its total sales.A study in September  by the National Union of Students found one in five university students don’t drink alcohol.Portsmouth Universitys Vice-Chancellor Graham Galbraith said: “We recognise that student tastes have changed in recent years and most students who want to drink alcohol would prefer to do so at other city venues.Only a minority of students have been using the Waterhole bar and we’re aware that many avoid it.Students’ Union President Helena Schofield added: “We are sad to see the bar go but we understand that it’s not financially viable to keep it open.”We’re excited to hear student ideas on what the new space should bring to the experience of students here in Portsmouth.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: iran rocket explodes space centre satellite
story: The launch, criticised by the US for allegedly being related to Irans illicit nuke programme, is the third such failure this year, it has been reported.State media and officials did not immediately acknowledge the incident at the Imam Khomeini Space Center in Irans Semnan province.However, satellite images by Planet Labs Inc. showed a black plume of smoke rising above a launch pad there, with what appeared to be the charred remains of a rocket and its launch stand.In previous days, satellite images had shown officials there repainted the launch pad blue.On Thursday morning, half of that paint apparently had been burned away.Whatever happened there, it blew up and youre looking at the smouldering remains of what used to be there, said David Schmerler of the Middlebury Institute of International Studies.Over the past decade, Iran has sent several short-lived satellites into orbit and in  launched a monkey into space.The US alleges such launches defy a UN Security Council resolution calling on Iran to undertake no activity related to ballistic missiles capable of delivering nuclear weapons.Iran, which long has said it does not seek nuclear weapons, maintains its satellite launches and rocket tests do not have a military component.Schmerler told The Associated Press that the images of the space centre suggested that the rocket either exploded during ignition or possibly lted off before crashing back down on the pad.Water runoff from the pad, likely from trying to extinguish the blaze, could be seen along with a host of vehicles parked nearby.NPR first reported on the satellite images of the apparent failed launch at the space centre, some  miles southeast of Irans capital Tehran.Iranian satellite launches had been anticipated before the end of the year.In July, Irans Information and Communications Technology Minister Mohammad Javad Azari Jahromi told the AP that Tehran planned three more launches this year, two for satellites that do remote-sensing work and another that handles communications.The Nahid- is reportedly the telecommunication satellite, which authorities plan to have in orbit for two-and-a-half months. Nahid in Farsi means Venus.The satellite, which had Irans first foldable solar , was supposed to be in a low orbit around the Earth for some two-and-a-half months.The semi-official Mehr news agency quoted Jahromi on Aug.  as saying that the Nahid- was ready to be delivered to Irans Defense Ministry, signalling a launch date for the satellite likely loomed.Irans National Week of Government, during which Tehran often inaugurates new projects, began August .Earlier today, Irans Defence Minister General Amir Hatami told the state-run IRNA news agency that the countrys satellite activities were being done in a transparent way, responding to AP and other foreign media reporting on activity at the space centre.Iran has also pledged to breach the agreement until it receives the sanctions relief it says it is owed.The deal was an agreement between the Islamic Republic and a group of world powers aimed at scrapping the Middle Eastern countrys nuclear weapons programme.It saw Iran agree to eliminate its stockpile of medium-enriched uranium by  per cent.Enriched uranium is a critical component for making nuclear weapons and in nuclear power stations and by curbing the amount Iran produce is a way to curb the number of weapons produced.As part of the agreement, Iran also agreed to only enrich their uranium up to . per cent over the next  years and they agreed to reduce their gas centruges for  years.Gas centruges are used to separate dferent types of uranium which allows specic types to then be used to manufacture nuclear weapons or generators.Iranian nuclear facilities were limited to a single facility with only first-generation centruges for  years and other nuclear facilities had to be converted into other use.In addition, they were barred from building any more heavy-water faculties - a type of nuclear reactor which uses heavy wateras a coolant to maintain temperatures in the reactor.Also under the agreement, the International Atomic Energy Agency was granted regular access to all Iranian nuclear facilities to ensure Iran maintains the deal.If Iran abided by the deal it was promised relief from the US, European Union, and the United Nations Security Council on all nuclear-related economic sanctions.The agreement was reached on July , , and the world powers signed it in Vienna.Whenever activity and research bear successful results, we will announce the good news, Hatami said.Iran at times in the past hasnt acknowledged failed launches.The apparent attempt to launch the Nahid- comes after two failed satellite launches of the Payam and Doosti in January and February.A separate fire at the Imam Khomeini Space Centre in February also killed three researchers, authorities said at the time.I think it is certainly an image problem, said Michael Connell, an Iran analyst at the Arlington, Virginia-based nonprofit research organisation CNA.I think its going to embarrass the Iranian space agency. On the other hand though, getting a satellite into space ... takes time.Tehran also says it doesnt violate the UN as it only called upon Tehran not to conduct such tests.The tests have taken on new importance to the US amid the maximalist approach to Iran taken by President Donald Trumps administration.Tensions have been high between the countries since Trump unilaterally withdrew the U.S. from Irans nuclear deal over a year ago and imposed sanctions, including on Irans oil industry.Iran recently has begun to break the accord itself while trying to push Europe to help it sell oil abroad.

title: remainers mp office rees moggs home parliament suspension
story: Pro-EU voters are furious after Boris Johnson asked the Queen to suspend the Commons in the run-up to Brexit.This daring move will hobble Remainer efforts to stop a No Deal exit from the European Union on October .In response, an ex-Labour councillor candidate Howard Simpson tweeted out Mr Mogg’s home address demanding people turn up to protest.Mr Simpson later deleted his tweet, but not before hed told thousands to show up at the Brexiteer’s village in Somerset to demonstrate.Police have confirmed they were braced for a large demo outside the Commons Leader’s house this evening.As MPs geared up for a huge Brexit battle next week:And in extraordinary scenes today, Tory MP Alex Chalk, who actually voted Remain in the referendum, was forced to face down an angry mob outside his Cheltenham office.In a video clip, Mr Chalk – who is the Private Secretary to Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab - attempted to calm down his constituents telling that the move to suspend Parliament sent out the “wrong” message.And when the MP joked: “What can you do, bring down the government ”, the crowd cheered loudly.This comes as backers of the Jeremy Corbyns grassroots group Momentum urged to “occupy bridges and blockade roads” to protest Boris plan to shut down Parliament.And they called for “Stop The Coup” protests in major cities across Britain for Saturday – followed by a mass demonstration on Tuesday in London to coincide with theof MPs to Westminster.Momentum national coordinator Laura Parker, who said she would occupy Parliamentshe had to, stormed: Real power doesn’t sit with the Queen or in Parliament. It’s with us the people – and that’s why we need to take action.Our message to Johnson is this:you steal our democracy, well shut down the streets.But Tories reacted with fury to Momentums ludicrous plan.David TC Davies told The Sun: Momentum seem to think that no one should do anything without their permission - and theyre going to block the streetsthey dont get their way.And its ironic that they are complaining about Parliament being shut down while they are stopping anyone from getting there at all.Another MP added: “They appear to be trying to ‘Stop the Coup’ as they put it by launching one of their own.”A former Labour MP – Tom Blenkinsop – tweeted that Momentum was “playing into the hands of the right” with their fury.It comes after thousands of people turned up to protest outside Downing Street and the Houses of Parliament last night.Spontaneous protests are being planned in Glasgow, Leeds, Liverpool, Manchester and Sheffield too.Earlier today Mr Rees-Mogg urged teeth-gnashing Remainers to change the law or boot the Government out -they can.The Commons leader led the Government fightback today against pro-EU MPs who have vowed to stop Boris Johnson shutting down Parliament next month.Mr Rees-Mogg told them to bring it on - and that the Government was ready.He told the BBC this morning: All these people who are wailing and gnashing of teeth know that there are two ways of doing what they want to do.One, is to change the government and the other is to change the law. If they do either of those, that will then have an effect.If they dont have either the courage or the gumption to do either of those then we will leave on the st of October in accordance with the referendum result.And he added: No party should be afraid of the British people.If they have a vote of confidence, lets seethey can win it.He said the outrage over shutting down Parliament was phoney and blasted Speaker Bercow for his insistent.The teasing came as he said that Mr Corbyn doesnt have enough mates to win such a vote.Nobody wants him to be PM, he joked, labelling those who are trying to thwart Brexit as spewing out phoney outrage because they want to stop us from leaving.They are trying very hard to overturn the referendum result, he blasted.Labours Barry Gardiner confirmed to Sky News today that Labour would apply for an emergency debate next week, and would seek to force Boris to get another Brexit extension.Yesterday Boris asked the Queen for her approval to suspend proceedings for nearly five weeks from as early as September  - and she accepted.Under the extraordinary move, the PM will be able to suspend Parliament no earlier than Monday, September  and no later than Thursday, September .

title: hurricane dorian walt disney world florida
story: The Category  storm is expected to strengthen into a potentially catastrophic Cat  with winds of  mph and slam into the US on Monday, the National Hurricane Centre said. And forecaster John Belski tweeted that the eye of the hurricane will be within five miles of Disney World as the storm howls through the sunshine state next week.However, its path could change within that time although Florida has declared a state of emergency as Dorian gains strength and speed as it hurtles across the Atlantic.Disney has told visitors to keep checking weather reports as local residents, who are no stranger to vicious storms, prepare for the worst.The House of Mouse, which is due to open new attraction Star Wars: Galaxys Edge despite the threat of Dorian, has not released an official statement and has not ed requests for comment.Flash flooding, mph winds and  inches of rain are some of the threats which the tornado could wreak upon the area.The storm - which will be the strongest hurricane to smash through central Florida in  years - has already battered the US Virgin Islands and is expected to strengthen to a Category  hurricane on Friday.Florida residents picked the shelves clean of bottled water and lined up at gas stations on Thursday.If it makes landfall as a Category  or  hurricane, thats a big deal, said University of Miami hurricane researcher Brian McNoldy.A lot of people are going to be affected. A lot of insurance claims.President Donald Trump cancelled his weekend trip to Poland and declared Florida is going to be totally ready.With the storms track still unclear, no immediate mass evacuations were ordered.Along Floridas east coast, local governments began distributing sandbags, shoppers rushed to stock up on food, plywood and other emergency supplies at supermarkets and hardware stores.Meanwhile, some fuel shortages were reported in the Cape Canaveral area.Josefine Larrauri, a retired translator, went to a Publix supermarket in Miami only to find empty shelves in the water section and store employees unsure of when more cases would arrive.I feel helpless because the whole coast is threatened, she said.Whats the use of going all the way to Georgiait can land there Tfany Miranda of Miami Springs waited well over  minutes in line at BJs Wholesale Club in Hialeah to buy hurricane supplies.Some  vehicles were bumper-to-bumper, waiting to fill up at the stores  gas pumps.You never know with these hurricanes. It could be good, it could be bad. You just have to be prepared, she said.Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency, clearing the way to bring in more fuel and call out the National Guardnecessary, and Georgias governor followed suit.At the Kennedy Space Centre at Cape Canaveral, NASA decided to move indoors the mobile launch  for its new mega rocket under development.The Saffir-Simpson Hurricane Wind Scale is based on a hurricanes sustained wind speed.Royal Caribbean and Carnival began rerouting their cruise ships.A Rolling Stones concert Saturday at the Hard Rock Stadium near Miami was moved up to Friday night.The hurricane season typically peaks between mid-August and late October.One of the most powerful storms ever to hit the US was on Labour Day .The unnamed Category  hurricane crashed ashore along Floridas Gulf Coast on Sept.  and was blamed for over  deaths.Dorian blew through the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico as a Category  hurricane on Wednesday.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A senior cabinet minister has been slapped down by Number  after being caught on camera apparently blurting out the reasons for Boris Johnson shutting down Parliament. The Prime Minister announced he was going to reboot Parliament in September, slashing the time MPs have to debate and block his Brexit plan.Number  say they want to hold a Queen’s Speech to set out their raft of domestic policies, and insist the timing has nothing to do with Brexit. But Johnson leads a minority government - and every sitting day increases the chances of his Brexit plan being defeated by opponents in Parliament. And today Number  said Defence Secretary Ben Wallace misspoke when he was filmed in an unguarded moment apparently admitting the move was about Brexit after all. Mr Wallace was seen speaking to French Defence Minister Florence Parly moments before a meeting of European counterparts in Helsinki, in footage broadcast by the BBC.    Ms Parly reportedly asked Mr Wallace about the plan to ‘prorogue’ Parliament. “Parliament has been very good at saying what it doesn’t want,” he said. “But it has been awful at saying what it does want, that’s the reality.” He went on: “So you know, eventually any leader has to, you know, try.” “I don’t know what the outcome of it…” he said, bursting into laughter. “You know…politics.”    He went on to explain that the real reason it was necessary to shut down Parliament to get a Brexit plan through was because Johnson doesn’t have the majority he needs to stop it being blocked. “Our system is a winner takes all system,” he said. “If you win a parliamentary majority you control everything. You control the timetable. There is no written separation. So it’s…you pretty much are in command of the whole thing. “And we’ve suddenly found ourselves with no majority and a coalition, and that’s not easy for our system.” A Number  source said: “The Defence secretary misspoke and was not involved in discussions about the Queen’s speech. The Queen’s speech will allow us to set out an ambitious legislative programme to deliver on our domestic priorities such as tackling violent crime, investing in our health service and tackling the cost of living.” But SNP MP Joanna Cherry, who is leading a legal challenge to the shutdown, said the clip backed up her teamaposs claim.  She tweeted: I’ve drawn this admission to the attention of our legal team. Defence Secretary backs up what we contend - that prorogation of Parliament is for an improper purpose  therefore unlawful. Labour MP Wes Streeting said: Telling the truth is a disciplinary offence under Boris Johnson’s regime. And Independent Group for Change MP Chris Leslie said: The shabby pretence that closing Parliament is anything other than a device to thwart majority of MPs makes this constitutional abuse more insulting.If they’re going to use authoritarian powers, at least be honest about why! But maybe it’s the cover-up that will trip them up.

They grew up free from the pressures of social media harassment, celeb culture, naked selfies, gender confusion and endless school testing. Throw in the fathomless idiocy of Love Island, end-of-the-world Greta Thunberg and internet porn, and you have a perfect cocktail of despair for today’s youngsters. No wonder the Children’s Society reports a “national scandal” of rapidly increasing child unhappiness. In the long holiday, our girls went out in the morning and came back in the evening. They went where they liked and did what they liked. Just like my time. As lads, we ran wild, summer and winter, in games we made up. We re-fought the Second World War with guns made from wood and nails. We skated down pit stacks on bits of conveyor belt.

When one in five of our kids is dangerously obese, the loss of  playgrounds since  in England alone is a self-defeating Conservative ideology recklessly gambling with lives. No single answer exists to reverse the obesity epidemic but encouraging the young to be physically active is – as the vast majority of parents know – part of the solution. So closing the areas where mums, dads and carers take children to have fun is a dead-end policy which Labour would urgently reverse. Cuts year after year to local authority budgets, sucking billions of pounds out of communities, was always a political move rather than an economic necessity.

title: what brexit voters most split
story: NewsHow city split almost equally by Brexit referendum would vote nowNewcastle was Britain’s most-split city - where Remainer Patricia Mennin, , feels "we are better as a group rather than on our own" but Leave voter Andy Heppell, , feels "the country needs some change"ShareCommentsByRachel EndleyEmika Berry:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsRemainer Patricia Mennin, , feels we are better as a group rather than on our own "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribe We will use your email address only for the purpose of sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNewcastle was Britain’s most-split city at the  Brexit referendum, with .% opting to Leave and .% to Remain. The Mirror visited to hear what voters think now. Patricia Mennin, , a retired civil servant from Newcastle, who voted Remain, said: “I think we are better off staying in. “I’d vote the same way again. I just think we are better as a group rather than on our own. “Boris Johnsonis doing it prorogation to stop people from preventing a no deal. “We are going to end up with a no deal and the prospect of that is scary.”  Andy Heppell , , a plumber from Durham, who voted Leave, said: “I’d vote the same way again, I think the country needs some change. “Boris is like Trump, he’s got a backbone. I think he is going to deliver Brexit . “If he says you are going to get an egg with your chips, you are going to get an egg with your chips. “I’m not fussedwe leave with a no-deal. The public have no control and Brexit has shown that.” Stuart McCabe , , a law student from Bedlington, Northumberland, who voted Leave, said: “I just feel the benefits of us being out are greater than they are for us being in and I would vote the same way again.  “People who say they don’t want a no-deal are just saying they don’t want Brexit. “Having a no-deal is not a condition of leaving the EU. I would be happy with a no-deal. “The way the MPs have handled Brexit is a complete drama. They’re acting like it’s a complete shock still, three years on.” Janice Greathead , , a teaching assistant from Ashington, who voted to leave the EU, said: “The way the MPs have handled it is terrible.    “They are disgusting. They have dragged it out for so long. “It’s like they are pushing people to change their minds. There’s been so much scaremongering on both sides. “I don’t think there should be another referendum before we leave. ButI had to vote again I would vote the same way - to vote us out of the EU.” Ellie Greathead , , an accountancy student of Northumbria University who was too young to vote in the referendum but would now vote to Remain, said: “I don’t see why we are suspending Parliament.  It’s like he’s forcing the Government into a no-deal. “He is not giving the Government a chance to sort it. “The public have just been left bewildered. No-one knows what is going to happen. It is just total confusion.” Esther Choudhury, , a nurse from Gateshead, who voted Remain, said: “Voting ‘in’ just made more sense economically. “I would definitely vote the same waywe were to vote again. “I want to like Boris Johnson but as Prime Minister, suspending Parliament was a bad move.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has vowed to leave the EU on October  - with or without a Brexit deal. And Downing Street insiders now believe crashing out of the EU without a deal to be the most likely outcome on Halloween. MPs may try to block a no-deal Brexit by voting to bring down the government. But the Prime Minister attempted to thwart them by proroguing Parliament for more than a month. No Deal been talked about for years. Theresa May secured a deal which MPs then voted down three times the EU delayed the date of Brexit twice and now Boris Johnson will only accept a deal which strips out the Northern Ireland Backstop. But the whole time no-deal has been the backup plan - with Theresa May committing £billion or so, and Boris Johnson adding another £. billion to the cost.    That includes a huge advertising campaign - costing more than £, to encourage the public to prepare for a chaotic exit. So what does it actually mean in practical terms  If thereaposs no arrangement in time, weaposll lose  international trade deals in a blink, shed access to EU criminal databases and face the prospect of goods checks between Northern Ireland and the Republic. The government published  technical notices over  and  outlining the practical effects of no-deal - from driving licences to cats.    UK officials also unveiled aposday oneapos tarfs that would slap £, on the cost of a family car from the EU - but leave % of goods imports, including steel, tarf free. This could threaten struggling UK industries with a flood of cheap imports, but would also prevent searing price hikes that hit your wallet in the short term. Meanwhile ministers had , troops held at readiness, could call up Army reserves and declare martial law. Supermarkets and pharma giants were told to stockpile food and medicine. A lot of the effects are on business. UK farmers face a nine-month wait for approval to export organic goods to the EU. Fishermen could be blocked from EU waters. And manufacturers fear their supply chains drying up. But businesses are not what whoaposve written this guide for. Instead we have tried to establish  ways no-deal Brexit will affect you, the reader and your everyday le.  What is a no-deal Brexit  No Deal is the default optionMPs, the EU and the UK government canapost agree a Brexit aposWithdrawal Agreementapos by the Brexit deadline . The current -page deal, on the table since November , would have ensured businesses arenapost cut off by continuing rules in a apostransition periodapos until December . However, it came at a cost - a aposbackstopapos that could trap the UK in an EU customs union from . That means MPs and Boris Johnson opposed it. Mr Johnson has vowed to re-open talks on the deal, including dumping the backstop, despite the EU refusing to do so. If that fails, it leads us to a no-deal Brexit. Leaving with no deal will mean falling back on World Trade Organisation trade tarfs - increasing the price of imports and exports - and could leave legal aposblack holesapos where EU law stood before. The UK government has been ramping up preparations for no deal since the beginning of summer . After Boris Johnson took power, spending on no-deal preparations topped £billion. What is Boris Johnsonaposs plan for no-deal Brexit   Plan Ais to renegotiate Theresa Mayaposs original, -page Brexit deal and come out with a deal on October . Plan B is to leave with no deal, but get a standstill arrangement from November  onwards to prevent crippling new tarfs. Plan Cis to leave with no deal and no standstill arrangement. Experts say Plan B in particular is complete fantasy land. Boris Johnson claims he can use Article  of the General Agreement on Tarfs and Tradeto stop new tarfs springing up. This is called a managed no-deal - arranging lots of mini-deals to help smooth the path of leaving the EU. But GATT  says a plan and schedule must already be in place to form a customs union or free trade area, within a reasonableof time. That doesnapost include a no-deal Brexit . What does the governmentaposs financial watchdog say about no-deal Brexit  no-deal Brexit would trigger a year-long UK recession in just a few monthsapos time, the governmentaposs official spending watchdog predicted in July . The Office for Budget Responsibility said a recession would begin in the final three months of the UK leaves without agreement on October . The pound would drop in value instantly by % - while unemployment would rise by more than a quarter. GDP would fall % by the end of , around the same as the early s recession and a third of what was seen in the  financial crisis. In all no-deal would add about £billion a year to government borrowing from , the OBR said - or, put another way, £million a week. That in turn would hike the UKaposs net debt by % of GDP by March . Despite the drastic findings, OBR forecasters said their stress test was by no means a worst-case scenario.     ways no-deal Brexit could hit you NOTE: This information was gleaned mainly from government no-deal preparedness documents and advice over the last year. Some of these situations may be avoidedthere is a managed no-deal. . Martial law could be imposed with thousands of troops on standby  More than , troops are being held at readiness in case there is a disastrous no-deal Brexit. Army reserves are also legally able to be called upthere is civil unrest, while councils are braced for possible runs on banks, fuel and food. Local Resilience Forums are reporting back to Whitehall and expect several months of disruptionthere is no deal. The government has plans in case it needs to impose martial law - military law - and curfews to restore order. Cabinet minister Matt Hancock admitted the plans existed but insisted the government was not specically looking at martial law and it was not the focus of our attention. . You need to renew your passport early  At the moment, British citizens can enter aposSchengen areaapos countries with a valid passport eventhey only have a day left before they expire. But in a no deal Brexit, after  October  you may not be able to travel to these countriesyou have less than six months left on your passport. The government is advising travellers to renew any passports older than nine years and six months. . Usually this means renewing six months before your passport expires. Butyour passport had more than  yearsapos validity, youaposll have to renew earlier, because the extra months on top of  years donapost count. The following are members of the Schengen Agreement: Austria, Belgium, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Estonia, Finland, France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Iceland, Italy, Latvia, Liechtenstein, Lithuania, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Portugal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden and Switzerland. . Pet owners must visit the vet FOUR MONTHS before a holiday  There is a huge surge in red tape for pet owners who want to take their beloved animals abroad. Currently dogs , cats and ferrets can travel anywhere in the EU as long as they have a pet passport. The main requirement is that three weeks before the first visit, owners must go to the vet to have their pet vaccinated against rabies and microchipped. But in the worst case no-deal Brexit, pet owners must visit a vet at least four months before taking their pet the EU. And because talks are ongoing, that means youaposd better book in now. The animal must have a rabies vaccination followed by a blood test at least  days later, to prove the vaccination worked. Pet owners must then wait at least three months before visiting the vet to obtain a health certicate. But this cannot be done more than  days before the date the holiday starts.  . KFC and other big names could run out of food - and water supplies could be affected  Food is being stockpiled forwe crash out of the EU without a deal, and ministers have promised an adequate supply.  But thataposs not the same as having the range of food we do now. Leaked plans in December warned Brits could have to y their diet.  And in January, big names KFC, Pret, Lidl, Co-Op, MS, Waitrose, Sainsburyaposs, Asda and McDonaldaposs signed a damning letter warning food supplies could run short because of disruptions to the supply chain. They wrote in a joint letter to MPs: Our ability to mitigate these risks is limited.   As prudent businesses we are stockpiling where possible, but all frozen and chilled storage is already being used and there is very little general warehousing space available in the UK.  They added: Retailers typically store no more than two weeksapos inventory and it becomes dficult to restock storesthe supply chain is disrupted. Leaked preparations under the governmentaposs Operation Yellowhammer warned some fresh food stocks will be affected and hundreds of thousands of people will be hit by problems with water supply. While there will not be overall food shortages, a combination of factors “will reduce availability and choice and increase the price”. Poorest families would be worst hit and “there is a risk that panic buying will disrupt food supplies”. There is also a warning of a “failure in the chemicals supply chain” for water. “The likelihood of this is considered low, affecting hundreds of thousands of people. Urgent action may need to be taken to make sure people have access to clean water.” . You could lose your job  A string of firms have either moved jobs out of the UK or are threatening to do so in a no-deal situation. Airbus, which employs , people in the UK with around , more jobs in supply chains, warned it may move where. Car plants are moving forward standard shutdowns to be around Brexit in case there are supply chain issues. And critics fear new investment will not come the UKaposs way, hitting jobs in generations More jobs could be lost due to oil refineries shutting down according to the Operation Yellowhammer document . Petrol supplies could be hit, oil refineries could shut and , workers lose their jobs. Panic-buying could create shortages, such as those seen during the  fuel crisis. The briefing says: “Traffic disruption caused by border delays could affect fuel distribution in the local area, particularlytraffic queues in Kent block the Dartford Crossing, which would disrupt fuel supply in London and the South East. “Customer behaviour could lead to shortages in other parts of the country.” Strikes over job losses at refineries could unleash disruption for two weeks. . Your motorway commute faces becoming a lorry park  UPDATE: After the October extension was agreed, Highways England deactivated Operation Brock until further notice. You can find the latest updates here. Major motorways in the South of England are set for serious disruption in case of a no-deal Brexit. From aposearly apos the Mwill be closed as needed from junctions -, with a contraflow of both directions on the opposite side, so it can be used as a lorry parkthere is gridlock at Dover. A backup lorry park will be in place at Manston Airport. The M in Kent is also expected to be used as a holding area for lorries. And a similar fate could befall a -mile stretch of the M towards Southampton. The Treasuryaposs additional £. billion no-deal Brexit fund, announced in early August , includes more cash to improve transport infrastructure around the Kent coast. The leaked Operation Yellowhammer document also warned Lorries using Channel ports may not be ready for French customs checks. It says: “The lack of traders’ readiness combined with limited space in French ports to hold HGVs could reduce [traffic] flow rates to %-% of current levels within a day. “The worst disruption might continue for three months before flow rates rise to %-%, although disruption could continue for much longer. “The French might act to ensure some flow through the crossings. HGVs could face a maximum delay of one and a half to two and a half days to cross the border.” . Millions of plane tickets could be cancelled  UPDATE: In March  the EU and UK agreed in principle to an reciprocal arrangement which would keep planes in the air for a year after the original exit date of  March  even in a no deal scenario. Itaposs unclear whether this will now apply for a year after  October. The International Air Transport Associationwarn up to million plane tickets could be cancelledthere is no deal. Currently it is not known exactly which tickets could be hit, or how passengers would find outthey are at risk. The situation arose because in a aposno dealapos, there will be no automatic legal basis for flights between the EU and UK after pm on  March . Under a pact struck between the UK and EU in December, basic connectivity will be maintained for a -month periodthereaposs no-deal. But according to the IATA - which represents  airlines including British Airways - that only means maintaining the number of flights in . It does not allow an increase in services - yet tickets have already been sold based on a predicted increase. Talks are ongoing, but Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office, previously warned flights could be groundedgoodwill fails. . Youaposll find it harder to drive in the EU  Currently a UK driving licence is the only thing visitors need to get behind the wheel on the continent. But under a no-deal Brexit, you should get an International Driving Permit. The £. documents were due to be sold at , post offices from February. Before they were sold at fewer than . The number of permits issued would have to soar from , a year to million. Meanwhile you will also be forced to apply for a aposgreen cardapos to prove you have the right car insurance. The certicates are free of charge and available from insurance companies. But the government warns firms may increase administration fees in order to cope with the extra bureaucracy. Those who forget their green cards would be forced to buy expensive frontier insurance in the country they are visiting. . Up to a million Brits may be forced to take a new driving test  British people driving in Europe could be forced to take a new driving testthereaposs a no deal Brexit. Up to a million Brits living in Europe were told to replace their driving licence with a local permit immediately. Guidance issued by the Department for Transport said: If you are a UK licence holder living in the EU or EEA you should exchange your UK driving licence for a local EU driving licence before  March . From that date, in the event that there is no EU Exit deal, you may have to pass a driving test in the EU country you live in to be able to carry on driving there. . If youaposre an EU citizen, youaposll have fewer rights to stay in the UK  More than million EU citizens living in the UK will have less concrete rights to stay. Whether thereaposs a Brexit deal or not, EU citizens can stay in Britainthey register for settled status with the government. But the rules are stricter in a no-deal Brexit. In no-deal, only EU citizens arriving before October  can apply, not those arriving by December . The deadline to apply will be  December , instead of  June there is a Brexit deal. And family members will only be able to join settled EU citizens in the UK before  March . As for the other way round - major EU nations have inidually said theyaposll allow UK ex-pats to stay, but this could y by country. And the rules could become stricter, with Home Secretary Priti Patel working on a crackdown to take effect on Day One of a no-deal Brexit. . Pharmacies and hospitals could start rationing medicine  Pharmacists have requested special powers to ration medicinesthere is no Brexit deal Under plans by the Healthcare Distribution Association, they would have special powers to y doctorsapos prescriptions and offer something a drug is unavailable.  million packs of medicines are imported to the UK from the EU every month, and the NHS is preparing for a doomsday scenario to prevent supplies running dry. Government and NHS chiefs have set up a war room called the aposOperational Response Centreapos and industry firms are creating six-week stockpiles of medicine. Health Secretary Matt Hancock chartered a plane to fly in short-shelf-le products, like isotopes for cancer treatment, from Maastricht. Insulin could also be stockpiled. Mr Hancock claimed heaposd become the biggest buyer of fridges in the world, after fitting out facilities for storage of the crucial drugs. NHS staff are being directed to urge patients not to stockpile medicines personally to avoid shortages throughout the system. The Operation Yellowhammer document warned: While some products can be stockpiled, others cannot because of short shelf lives. It will not be practical to stockpile six months’ supplies.” Three-quarters of drugs arrive via Folkestone and Dover, making them “particularly vulnerable to severe delays”. Medicines for diabetes, some leukaemia treatments and flu vaccinations must be transported under temperature controls. “Supply chains are also highly regulated and require transportation that meets strict Good Distribution Practices. This can include limits on transit times.” The leaked document also warned social care could be hit by rising inflation - leaving operators facing collapse within months. “The adult social care market is already fragile because of the declining financial viability of providers. “An increase in inflation after the UK’s EU exit would affect providers of adult social care through increasing staff and supply costs and might lead to failure within two-three months for smaller providers and four-six months for larger ones. “Intelligence will be gathered to prepare for effects on the sector, including closure of services and handing back of contracts that are not part of the normal market .” . Your mobile phone roaming charges may be hiked  Mobile roaming charges face an immediate hikethere is a no-deal Brexit, the government has confirmed. Tory ministers are revoking the EU law which guarantees UK citizens pay the same for using their phone on the Continent as they do at home. That will leave mobile phone firms free to hike costs whenever they like after the UK leaves. Guaranteed free roaming launched across the EU just  months ago - and meant big savings. But that guarantee will be scrappedthere is no deal, thanks to an obscure law laid before Parliament. . You should get insurance and flexible tickets for Eurostar aposdisruptionapos  Eurostar services could be suspended in a worst-case no deal Brexit. The government has told international train passengers - including the Eurostar - to make sure they have insurance and ticket terms and conditions that are sufficient to cover possible disruption. That implies passengers should buy FLEXIBLE tickets - not the fixed cheap ones that are popular for their low cost. The UK will need bilateral deals with France, Belgium and the Netherlands to ensure international trains keep running. Without such a deal, Britain has proposed recognising EU operator licences until March  to ensure services can continue. But this isnapost guaranteed, and UK operators would have to reapply with the EU. The EU has agreed to keep permissions for services like the Channel Tunnel open for three monthsthere is no-deal, while a new agreement is negotiated. But there arenapost guarantees. Former Transport Secretary Andrew Adonis claimed the vital train link between Britain and Europe could be severed. . You might have to go through airport security twice  Air passengers changing flights in the EU may have to undergo two security screenings under a no-deal exit.  Travellers boarding a plane in the UK to fly to a European airport, before changing flights for an onward destination, would be screened in Britain as they are now.  But they might have to have a second check in the EU before getting their connecting flight.  “Currently passengers flying from the UK and transferring at an EU airport for an onward flight do not have to be re-screened at that EU airport, because the UK applies, and exceeds, the EU baseline aviation security measures,” says a Department for Transport briefing note.  “If there is no deal, and the EU decides not to recognise the UK aviation security system, then passengers and their luggage will have to be re-screened when changing flights in EU hub airports.”  . You could be barred from using Netflix and Spoty on holiday  Britons could be barred from accessing their accounts for Netflix, Spoty and other online entertainment while travelling to EU statesthereaposs a no-deal Brexit. Under the EU-wide portability regulation, which took force in April, citizens can access accounts set up and based in one country while visiting other member states. But a government technical notice said: The portability regulation will cease to apply to UK nationals when they travel to the EU. This means online content service providers will not be required or able to offer cross-border access to UK consumers under the EU Regulation. UK consumers may see restrictions to their online content services when they temporarily visit the EU. . If you live in Northern Ireland, you face electricity blackouts  Northern Ireland will be forced to take drastic measures to stop the lights going out. A worst-case no-deal Brexit would scupper the all-island electricity market shared by Northern Ireland and the Republic - leaving it without any legal basis. This would make both markets less efficient, with potential effects for producers and consumers on both sides of the border, the government warns. And it may be necessary to seek additional [legal] powers to preserve security of supply. To stop the lights going out, Northern Ireland would have to take more electricity from British power stations through an interconnector running under the Irish Sea. But Northern Irelandaposs Transmission System Operator may need to rely on fall-back arrangements to ensure power keeps flowing, the government warns. That is why, eventhereaposs a no deal, the government will take all possible measures to keep the all-island market running. There has been talk of barges in the Irish Sea. Dustin Benton of Green Alliance warned:Any emergency action to keep the lights on, both in Northern Ireland and across the rest of the UK, would likely be highly polluting and expensive. . You could be stranded on your package holiday  Package holidaymakers could be left with no legal protectionthe firm they booked with goes bust. Currently Brits have insolvency protectionthey book with a package holiday provider thataposs based anywhere in the EU. But in a no-deal Brexit, that protection would only applythe firms are targeting the UK market. That means those booking with, say, a cheaper Spanish firm online that has no UK presence could be unprotected. Eventhe UK government could act, in practice it will be much harder to take enforcement action against foreign firms because other countries will no longer recognise UK courts. And the leaked Operation Yellowhammer document warns passengers travelling to and from the EU may face more immigration checks. “UK citizens travelling to and from the EU may be subject to increased immigration checks at border posts. This may lead to passenger delays at St Pancras, Channel Tunnel and Dover, where border controls are juxtaposed. “Depending on what plans EU member states put in place to cope with these increased checks, it is likely delays will occur for UK arrivals and departures at EU airports and ports. This could cause some disruption on transport services. Travellers may decide to use alternative routes.” . Youaposll lose rights to take action over dangerous products  Government documents reveal the same problem - UK courts not being recognised - will strip Brits of their consumer rights for EU goods bought online. Alex Neill of consumer group Which  warned: A no-deal Brexit would massively weaken peopleaposs rights to take action when they purchase faulty or dangerous products from outside the UK. The Governmentaposs advice that we all become experts in international consumer law is hopelessly unrealistic. Securing a good deal with the EU is vital to ensure that Brexit doesnapost result in a bonfire of consumer rights and protections.” . Your cigarette packets will change  Graphic warnings on cigarette packets will be replaced by Australian versions in a no-deal Brexit. And in some ways they are even more gruesome than the ones we have now. The grim pictures show a foot ridden with peripheral vascular disease, a clogged artery, a bleeding brain and high-resolution teeth stained black. The photos will be changed in a no-deal Brexit because the European Commission owns theon ones we currently use. That means the UK would be unable to use them after  October . . If youaposre going through a family breakdown, you could be trapped in limbo  Families who are midway through orce or child custody cases involving another EU country could find themselves trapped in limbo. If there’s a no deal Brexit, the UK will cease to be part of co-operation between EU family courts on  October . Instead the UK will fall back on legal conventions drawn up in The Hague. But these are complicated and do not cover every area of the law. The government has advised families with ongoing cases to seek legal advicethey will not finish by Brexit Day. A government technical note says: Broadly speaking, cases ongoing on exit day will continue to proceed under the current rules. However, we cannot guarantee that EU courts will follow the same principle, nor that EU courts will accept or recognise any judgments stemming from these cases.” . Your everyday medicines and perfumes could become more expensive  Currently, popular ingredients in cold medicines can usually be traded within the EU without a licence. In a no deal, a licence will be required to trade these so-called precursors. Sowe leave without a deal, firms who want to trade such chemicals with the EU will have to register with the Home Office, which can cost between £ and £,. They will also need an import export license, which costs £. Critics say this could push up prices for consumers in the shops. Similarly, cosmetics firms will be slapped with more red tape to prove their products are safe for human health. Currently they can use one legal “nominated person” to certy a product for the whole EU market. Butthere’s a no deal Brexit, UK checks won’t be recognised in the EU - and EU checks wonapost be recognised in the UK. That means two sets of checks. Labour MP Owen Smith claimed drug giants will look to pass on the costs. And finally... your regular caviar parties are doomed!  Caviar imports will be snarled up or stop completely in a no-deal Brexit. Sturgeon eggs join snowdrops, orchids and reptiles in aposendangered speciesapos that would need import and export permits to cross an EU border. Youaposd only be allowed to bring in g of caviar for personal use.

If you see your local shop on the list, get down there tonight and show your support. Best of luck to all of them in the next round.
